title: Your half term holiday just got more expensive as pound sinks against the euro
text:
Your half term holiday just got more expensive as pound sinks against the euro Your half term holiday just got more expensive as pound sinks against the euro BRITISH families planning a trip to Europe during the October half-term will see their spending power cut after the pound hit a five-month low against the euro this week. PUBLISHED: 12:04, Fri, Oct 16, 2015 | UPDATED: 13:46, Fri, Oct 16, 2015 GETTY Half term getaways could be more expensive than in the summer 
Sterling reached multi-year highs of €1.44 in July boosting the value of summer holidays for millions of British families who travelled abroad. 
But since the end of August the pound has weakened, and this week reached as low as €1.33 off the back of news that the UK is back in deflation. 
There has since been a small recovery to €1.36 over the past couple of days and the pound is still a lot strong than it was at this time last year. 
Furthermore, Europe is also in deflation, which means that prices are dropping. 
But parents have been urged to plan their holiday money carefully to make sure they get the most amount of euros for their pound as possible. 
FAIRFX currency expert Darren Kilner said: "With many families planning a holiday for half term and with holiday prices being pushed up, it’s important to ensure you’re making the most of your spending money by planning now.“Whatever you do, don’t leave sorting out your spending money until the last minute as you could be left severely out of pocket. "Exchange rates can be more than 10 per cent more expensive at airports than elsewhere meaning that you could lose £100 of your cash for every £1,000 you change." Related articles
